case_title: Muhammad Ameen vs Deputy Commissioner Panjgur

defense: Counsel for the petitioner (Name not provided)

complaint_summary: Petitioner sought compensation for land affected by road construction in District Panjgur. Compensation for date trees was provided, but no compensation for land was granted. Petitioner alleged delay and non-resolution by the respondent.
investigation_summary: Petitioner failed to provide title documents for the land in question. Documents submitted included a judgment from Qazi Court dated 26.05.2009, which did not establish ownership. Government of Balochistan claimed ownership of the land.
judgment_summary: The court dismissed the petition, stating that the petitioner failed to establish clear legal ownership of the land. The matter was deemed unsuitable for adjudication under constitutional jurisdiction and recommended for resolution in a civil court.
legal_arguments: Petitioner failed to provide title documents.
Disputed ownership of land requires adjudication in civil court.
Constitutional jurisdiction under Article 199 requires clear legal rights without controversy.
statutes: Article 199 of the Constitution of Islamic Republic of Pakistan, 1973
key_issues: Compensation for land affected by road construction

maxims.Legal Right: A party seeking constitutional remedy must establish a clear legal right devoid of reasonable doubt or controversy.

legal_terms.Constitutional Jurisdiction: Jurisdiction exercised under Article 199 for expeditious remedies in cases of clear legal rights.

words_and_phrases.Maintainability: Suitability of a petition for adjudication under specific jurisdiction.

summary_vector_notes: Petitioner sought compensation for land affected by road construction but failed to provide title documents. Court dismissed the petition, citing lack of clear legal ownership and recommended civil court adjudication.
